pullRequest.title: Add option to do more precise ACL checks
pullRequest.bodyText:
Before this change, Presto would check for column access permission on
all columns referenced in any part of the query.
This behavior can sometimes be undesirable, for example, in this query:
SELECT name FROM (SELECT * FROM nation)
During execution of this query, access checks would be performed on all
columns in the table nation, even though only the column name would
actually be read during the execution of the query, and the other
columns in the table have no impact on the query results.
This change introduces a new sesion property,
check_access_control_on_utilized_columns_only, which, when
enabled, will only perform access control checks on columns that would
actually be required to produce the query output, ignoring columns that
are referenced in the query, but are not required to compute the query
results.
Test plan -

Unit tests to cover a good range of query shapes.
Test on production workload queries

== RELEASE NOTES ==

General Changes
* Add session property ``check_access_control_on_utilized_columns_only``, which, when enabled, only performs access control checks on columns that would actually be required to produce the query output, ignoring columns that are referenced in the query, but are not required to compute the query results.

nodes.bodyText: Make the constructor private and add a static function that analyzes it - stylistically better.
You should not need the setter?
Add a helper function in Analysis that takes a table and returns columns so all the access checking logic is in one place.
I thought we originally thought we could use the maps from Analysis for this work? That didn't work out? One issue here is if we add some new clauses you might miss them if there is no visitor.
The name of the session is not clear. This is describing what it does rather than what it achieves. So maybe change to "check_access_control_on_referenced_columns_only" or something along that line.

beforeCommit.message:
Add option to do ACL checks only on those columns that won't be pruned

Before this change, Presto would check for column access permission on
all columns referenced in any subquery. This behavior can sometimes be
undesirable, for example, in the query:
``SELECT name FROM (SELECT * FROM nation)``
During execution of this query, access checks would be performed on all
columns in the table nation, even though only the column ``name`` would
actually be read during the execution of the query.

This change introduces a new sesion property,
``check_access_control_after_column_pruning``, which, when enabled,
will only perform access control checks on columns that would actually
be read. The column pruning is only done on columns that can be pruned
from an analysis of the SQL text (excluding column pruning rules that
rely on metadata statistics).

afterCommit.message:
Add option to do more precise ACL checks

Before this change, Presto would check for column access permission on
all columns referenced in any part of the query.
This behavior can sometimes be undesirable, for example, in this query:

``SELECT name FROM (SELECT * FROM nation)``

During execution of this query, access checks would be performed on all
columns in the table nation, even though only the column ``name`` would
actually be read during the execution of the query, and the other
columns in the table have no impact on the query results.

This change introduces a new sesion property,
``check_access_control_on_impacting_columns_only``, which, when
enabled, will only perform access control checks on columns that would
actually impact the query output.

nodes.bodyText: The word "impacting" is quite confusing to me. Does this have a specific meaning in SQL / language / compiler? I felt "referenced" makes more sense.

nodes.bodyText: A better style would be to send the session object to the function and do the flag check there for better encapsulation.
Need more join coverage - especially using nested subqueries and where clauses.
Add some tests for group by ordinals - GROUP BY 1,2 etc.
How about the columns of t2? Don't you need access for that?

Add :
select a,b from (select a,b,c,d from T1 union all select w,x,y,z from T2) where c = 0 and d = c

We also have things in where clause so check that
FB_NECTAR_SAMPLING_PCT(CAST(cms_business_id AS VARCHAR)) < 0.01

Also from a subquery:
cross join unnest(select array[x] from T) AS T(a)
should acl T.x
Add some array. map constructors and lambdas like transform/filter/reduce as they are widely used.

nodes.bodyText: Generally we rarely return mutable containers in Presto codebase. So instead of have this method and call getUtilizedTableColumnReferences.put(...), it's preferable to introduce a function addUtializedTableColumnRefereces(...). Correspondingly, it's probably better for the next function to return ImmutableMap.copyof(...).

commit.message:
Add option to do more precise ACL checks

Before this change, Presto would check for column access permission on
all columns referenced in any part of the query.
This behavior can sometimes be undesirable, for example, in this query:

``SELECT name FROM (SELECT * FROM nation)``

During execution of this query, access checks would be performed on all
columns in the table nation, even though only the column ``name`` would
actually be read during the execution of the query, and the other
columns in the table have no impact on the query results.

This change introduces a new sesion property,
``check_access_control_on_utilized_columns_only``, which, when
enabled, will only perform access control checks on columns that would
actually be required to produce the query output, ignoring columns that
are referenced in the query, but are not required to compute the query
